document.docTitle: Leptocera argentinica Buck & Marshall 2009, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of New World Leptocera Olivier (Diptera, Sphaeroceridae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description . Body length 2.1–3.3 mm . Habitus and head as in Figs. 36 and 2 . Coloration lighter than in most other species: Medium brown with frontal vitta, part of face (sometimes), inner surfaces of pedicel and first flagellomere, parafacial and gena (at least in part) reddish yellow; palpus, inner surface of fore coxa, mid trochanter, base of fore femur medially, knees, tibiae (sometimes: especially fore and mid tibia), as well as mid and hind tarsi pale brown. Head and thorax with strong grey pruinosity (better developed than in other species except
L. gongylotheca
sp.n. ). Uppermost orbital setula usually exclinate and more or less reclinate, exceptionally inclinate and proclinate. Arista medium-pubescent. Palpus slender. Mid tibia with bristle above distal dorsal about 0.5–0.6x as long as distal anterodorsal bristle; lowermost bristle of proximal posterodorsal series shorter than lowermost bristle of anterodorsal series; posteroapical bristles short, ventral one slightly to clearly longer than dorsal one.

Male terminalia indistinguishable from
L. gongylotheca
sp.n. (see Figs. 69–72 ). Sternite 5 with few long bristles posterolaterally, medially in front of field of enlarged microtrichia with small, pale, microtrichose area, hind margin with (4–)5(–6) long, strong scales of subequal length. Epandrium with moderately numerous long bristles ventrally. Anterior section of surstylus with apex of anterior process abruptly bent outward (ventral view), nearly perpendicular to main axis of body, ventral lobe little produced, with few, mostly short bristles. Posterior section of surstylus with fairly long, medially directed, semitransparent process anteriorly at base (best seen in lateral or ventral view); inner margin produced into prominent, rounded angle (posterior view), dorsomedial margin desclerotized, apex with two strong bristles (both with pointed tips but inner one much more tapered), posterior surface with few long, pale hairs in lateral half. Cercus with both finger-like and transparent, lamellate medial processes. Postgonite with wide posterobasal notch ( Fig. 139 ).

Type material .

Etymology . This species is named after the country in which most specimens were collected.
Distribution . From east Bolivia (Dpto. Santa Cruz) to southern Argentina ( Santa Cruz Province ). The species shows a remarkable elevation range (sea level to 3,650 m ).

Discussion . This species and the closely related
L. gongylotheca
sp.n. can be diagnosed by the fairly extensive reddish yellow coloration of the head, the unusually strong pruinosity of the body as well as several details of the male genitalia: apex of anterior process of anterior section of surstylus bent outward rectangularly, inner margin of the latter produced into a prominent rounded angle, lateral one of the two apical bristles of posterior section more pointed than in other species. Except for the completely different shape of the spermathecae we could find no morphological character that separates this species from the sympatric
L. gongylotheca
sp.n. (see discussion under that species).
